p.mixed-citation: Leach's study appears in Claude Lévi-Strauss: The Anthropologist as Hero, ed. E. Nelson Hayes and Tanya Hayes (Cambridge, Mass. and London: MIT Press, 1970), pp. 47-60.
Critique, 325 (June 1974), pp. 541-571.

Anthropologie Structurale Deux (Paris: Pion, 1970), pp. 31-35. In Les Structures élémentaires de la parenté Lévi-Strauss had studied the prohibition of incest with regard to the system of reciprocity necessary to culture.
"The Structural Study of Myth," in Myth: A Symposium, ed. Thomas A. Sebeok (Bloomington and London: Indiana U. P., 1972, first publ. 1955), pp. 88-95.

With regard to the "meaning" of the Oedipus myth, Lévi-Strauss concludes that it "has to do with the inability, for a culture which holds the belief that mankind is autochthonous... to find a satisfactory transition between this theory and the knowledge that human beings are actually born from the union of man and woman... By a correlation of this type, the overrating of blood relations is to the underrating of blood relations as the attempt to escape autochthony is to the impossibility to succeed in it" (pp. 91-92).
Gouttebroze's study appears in Voyage, Quête, Pèlerinage dans la littérature et la civilisation médiévales (Aix-en-Provence : Ed. CUER MA, 1976), pp. 340-352.
De l'interprétation. Essai sur Freud (Paris: Le Seuil, 1965), cited in Gout- tebroze, p. 342.
Daniel Poirion, "L'ombre mythique de Perceval dans le Conte du Graal," CCM, XVI (1973), pp. 191-198. For Frappier's comments see "Le Graal et ses feux divergents," MP, XXIV (1971), pp. 374-440.
"Perceval," Yale French Studies, 55/56 (1977), pp. 253-279.
"The Structural Study of Myth," p. 99.

Cf. Octavio Paz, Claude Lévi-Strauss: An Introduction, trsl. J. S. Bernstein and Maxine Bernstein (Ithaca and London: Cornell U. P., 1970): in the Grail myth "illicit sexual union = resolution of a riddle which postulates the union of two contradictory terms; sexual abstinence = inability to ask" (pp. 32-33).

"De Chrétien de Troyes à Richard Wagner," in Parsifal: Programmheft I der Bayreuther Festspiele (Bayreuth : Verlag der Festspielleitung, 1975), pp. 1-9, 60-67. I am grateful to M. Lévi-Strauss who provided me with a copy of this paper.

In this regard the comments of Lévi-Strauss regarding Freud are of parti- cular interest: "Our interpretation may take into account, and is certainly applicable to, the Freudian use of the Oedipus myth... not only Sophocles, but Freud himself, should be included among the recorded versions of the Oedipus myth on a par with earlier or seemingly more 'authentic' versions" ("The Structural Study of Myth," pp. 92-93). As James A. Boon comments, "This is to say that he is not treating the Oedipus-myth-in-relation-to-the- experience-of-classical-Greeks. Rather, he is treating more generally various efforts to come to terms with several sets of contradictions, such as 'how one can be born from two.' Sophocles provides a version that can be interpreted as such an effort; so does Freud." See From Symbolism to Structuralism: Lévi-Strauss in a Literary Tradition (N.Y., Evanston, San Francisco and London: Harper and Row, 1972).

"Anthropologie sociale," Annuaire du Collège de France, 74e Année (Paris, 1974), pp. 303-309. For financial support for this part of my study I am grateful to the Research Council of the University of Massachusetts, Amherst.
The Raw and the Cooked: Introduction to a Science of Mythology, I, trsl. John Weightman and Doreen Weightman (N. Y. and Evanston: Harper and Row, 1969), p. 199.

Jacques Ribard terms the encounter with the penitents a "rappel inverse de la rencontre des chevaliers"; see Le Conte du Graal (Perceval), Anthologie thématique (Paris : Hatier, 1976), p. 40. See also the second section of Ribard's commentary, "De la stérilité à la fécondité et du silence à la parole," pp. 51-89.
"The Structural Study of Myth," p. 105.

Of the isolation of mythemes from collected versions of the myth, Paz remarks that "one of the characteristics of myths is the recurrence of certain themes and motifs. In this way, we can reconstruct incomplete versions and even discover mythemes which, for one or another reason, do not appear in any version" (pp. 28-29).
Anthropologie Structurale (Paris: Pion, 1958), p. 235. The passage in question is an addition to the chapter "La Structure des Mythes" as translated from "The Structural Study of Myth."

Jacques Roubaud hypothesizes that "le mystère sur la généalogie des person- nages de la famille du Graal chez Chrétien et dans tous les romans... est dû à la dissimulation d'une relation incestueuse": see "Généalogie morale des rois-pêcheurs," Change, XVI-XV11 (1973), pp. 228-247.
